1231.content:
Susan woke to find the will was still resting on her bedside table. Groggily she reached for the folded document, half-expecting it to vanish like a dream. It all still felt so unreal, so impossible.

However, the paper crinkled at her touch, and gave every impression of being real. Underneath the will form, the old, odd, red leather bound book still sat there.

It was unique, hand bound, and with the pages uneven. Reaching up she ruffled her long mane of coppery hair. Even if it was real, surely it was a joke. Half expecting her friends to leap out of the cupboard, she picked up the book and flicked through the the stiff pages.

The pages were hand-written with scratchy illustrations scattered throughout the book. The words decorated with spatters, were clearly written with a fountain pen.... or perhaps a quill. She added the last idea as an afterthought. The explanations, such as they were, were written in very old English, and really didn't clear anything up for her.

At the base of one page, a section of text was marked. Top and bottom, a red decorative swirl separated it from the rest of the text. The words between didn't seem to be any language she recognised. The letters were English, but made no sense.

It was only as she silently sounded them out her lips moving mutely as she read them. With a snorting gasp, she realised they were written phonetically, to be pronounced as they were written.

Susan read them a couple of times to herself, without a sound. Until nodding, she had the whole short passage clear in her head. Not sure what it was going to achieve if anything, or why she was doing this without any coffee in her system, she shrugged and started to speak.

- - - - -

Reaching the end, she stopped. A little disappointed, a little relieved, and somewhat embarrassed, nothing happened. No wild flashes of magic or anything else had materialised. Her stomach gurgled faintly in protest, and her thoughts turned to breakfast, and that warming, rousing cup of coffee.

Planting her hands on the bed, she went to stand up. But a dizzy spell stopped her, a weak trembling in her arms. Then an odd sensation in the pit of her stomach. The one she'd thought was hunger for her breakfast, shifted. It sank lower, and wider. At the same time, the feeling of trapped air, of bloating made her scowl in discomfort.

That was Rin Kayama for you. Once given a task, she'll finish that task no matter what. Others offer to help VERY often, but Rin was too stubborn to accept any help. The other waiters have noted that Rin tended to push herself too hard at times. Once, she twisted her ankle, and it took both the floor manager and the head waitress to convince her NOT to come into work.

This nature even bled into her personal life. Often, she would forgoe sleep or sometimes food to finish whatever she had set her mind to. This was what helped her when she first moved to America at 20 years old. Born in Japan, Rin had decided she wanted to live in America at age 16, and threw herself into preparing for that day.

Stubborn and hard-headed she may be, it did make her well-respected at her workplace, The Gallery of Alluring Restaurant. It was one of those fancy, high-end restaurants in Beverly Hills. Decorated to almost resemble a fancy art gallery, the restaurant had a reputation of high prices only the rich could afford (the cheapest menu option was nearly $200), but high-quality food. It thankfully paid well, and accepted most trained individuals, hence how Rin got to work there.

It also didn't hurt Rin's respect that she was quite pretty. Long black hair in a ponytail, black eyes, a slight tan, and a slightly curvy figure, with C cup breasts and a moderate butt, all helped to make her more noticable.

At that point, she noticed one table was finished with their meal, and ready to leave. It was occupied by only one person, a very pretty woman in very fashionable clothing with platinum blonde hair. Rin walked up to the table.

"Did you enjoy your meal, miss?" Rin asked.

"It was quite spectacular, yes." The woman replied. "And the service was simply marvelous. This is my first time visiting, and I love it."

"Well, thank you." Rin said. "We pride ourselves on the quality of our food. Will you be having dessert?"

"Oh, heavens no." The woman answered. "The meal enough was filling."

"Alright." Rin said. "You can take care of your bill upfront."

The woman nodded and reached into her purse. She then put something on the table, and got up to leave. Rin looked, and saw that the woman had left a very sizable tip... and a small black box.

"Um, miss? You left this box here." Rin said.

"Consider it part of your tip." The woman replied. "I'm sure you'll enjoy it." With a wink, the woman walked off.
